Transcript: [November 7, 1934]   Western Union Telegram  Received at 413 Peoples Street, Corpus Christi, Texas  1934 NOV 7 AM 7 35  DB 10 50 NL = TYLER TEX 6  LYNDON JOHNSON =   NUECES HOTEL CORPUS CHRISTI TEX =  DARLING I HAD SILLY GAY HECTIC DAY DURING WHICH GENE SAID BURIAL SERVICE OVER ME AND MR KING AND F D CHEERED FOR US AND I TRIED WITH NOT QUITE HUNDRED PERCENT SUCCESS TO THINK AS I PROMISED YOU MISSED NINE OCLOCK BUS HOME SO CAUGHT FIVE OCLOCK LOVE YOU =  BIRD.  [Transcript prepared by LBJ Library staff, January 2013]
Title: Telegram, Lady Bird Taylor to Lyndon Johnson, November 7, 1934
Creator: Claudia Alta "Lady Bird" Taylor (Johnson)
Abstract: In a telegram sent from Tyler, Texas, Lady Bird tells LBJ that she had a hectic day and is taking the 5:00 bus home.
Collection: The Personal Papers of Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson are a collection of correspondence between Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson that spans 1934 through 1968. During the Johnsons’ years in the White House, Dorothy Territo, a staff assistant who maintained files of high historical value, as well as family and genealogical material, had custody of the collection. In 1969, the files she kept came to Austin as part of President Johnson’s papers, which he had deeded to the U.S. government in August 1965.This collection includes the courtship letters between Lyndon Johnson and Claudia "Lady Bird" Taylor, from the period between their introduction and their marriage, September – November 1934.
Citation: “Telegram, Lady Bird Taylor to Lyndon Johnson, November 7, 1934,” Personal Papers of Lyndon B. and Lady Bird Johnson, LBJ Presidential Library, Dear Bird: The 1934 Courtship Letters, accessed November 27, 2016, http://archives.lbjlibrary.org/items/show/377.
